name: Hemingway - a Pursuit Race
body:
William Campbell had been in a pursuit
race with a burlesque show ever since Pittsburgh.
In a pursuit race, in bicycle racing,
riders start at equal intervals to ride after one
another. They ride very fast because the race
is usually limited to a short distance and if they
slow their riding another rider who maintains
his pace will make up the space that separated
them equally at the start. As soon as a rider
is caught and passed he is out of the race and
must get down from his bicycle and leave the
track. If none of the riders are caught the
winner of the race is the one who has gained the
most distance. In most pursuit races, if there
are only two riders, one of the riders is caught
inside of six miles. The burlesque show
caught William Campbell at Kansas City.
William Campbell had hoped to hold a slight
lead over the burlesque show until they reached
the Pacific coast. As long as he preceded the
burlesque show as advance man he was being
paid. When the burlesque show caught up with
him he was in bed. He was in bed when the
manager of the burlesque troupe came into his
room and after the manager had gone out he
decided that he might as well stay in bed. It
was very cold in Kansas City and he was in no
hurry to go out. He did not like Kansas City.
He reached under the bed for a bottle and
drank. It made his stomach feel better. Mr.
Turner, the manager of the burlesque show,
had refused a drink.
William Campbellâs interview with Mr.
Turner had been a little strange. Mr. Turner
had knocked on the door. Campbell had said:
âCome in!â When Mr. Turner came into the
room he saw clothing on a chair, an open suitcase,
the bottle on a chair beside the bed, and
some one lying in the bed completely covered
by the bed-clothes.
âMister Campbell,â Mr. Turner said.
âYou canât fire me,â William Campbell said
from underneath the covers. It was warm and
white and close under the covers. âYou canât
fire me because Iâve got down off my bicycle.â
âYouâre drunk,â Mr. Turner said.
âOh, yes,â William Campbell said, speaking
directly against the sheet and feeling the texture
with his lips.
âYouâre a fool,â Mr. Turner said. He
turned off the electric light. The electric light
had been burning all night. It was now ten
oâclock in the morning. âYouâre a drunken
fool. When did you get into this town?â
âI got into this town last night,â William
Campbell said, speaking against the sheet. He
found he liked to talk through a sheet. âDid
you ever talk through a sheet?â
âDonât try to be funny. You arenât funny.â
âIâm not being funny. Iâm just talking
through a sheet.â
âYouâre talking through a sheet all right.â
âYou can go now, Mr. Turner,â Campbell
said. âI donât work for you any more.â
âYou know that anyway.â
âI know a lot,â William Campbell said. He
pulled down the sheet and looked at Mr. Turner.
âI know enough so I donât mind looking
at you at all. Do you want to hear what I
know?â
âNo.â
âGood,â said William Campbell. âBecause
really I donât know anything at all. I was just
talking.â He pulled the sheet up over his
face again. âI love it under a sheet,â he said.
Mr. Turner stood beside the bed. He was a
middle-aged man with a large stomach and a
bald head and he had many things to do. âYou
ought to stop off here, Billy, and take a cure,â
he said. âIâll fix it up if you want to do it.â
âI donât want to take a cure,â William Campbell
said. âI donât want to take a cure at all.
I am perfectly happy. All my life I have been
perfectly happy.â
âHow long have you been this way?â
âWhat a question!â William Campbell
breathed in and out through the sheet.
âHow long have you been stewed, Billy?â
âHavenât I done my work?â
âSure. I just asked you how long youâve
been stewed, Billy.â
âI donât know. But Iâve got my wolf back,â
he touched the sheet with his tongue. âIâve had
him for a week.â
âThe hell you have.â
âOh, yes. My dear wolf. Every time I take
a drink he goes outside the room. He canât
stand alcohol. The poor little fellow.â He
moved his tongue round and round on the sheet.
âHeâs a lovely wolf. Heâs just like he always
was.â William Campbell shut his eyes and
took a deep breath.
âYou got to take a cure, Billy,â Mr. Turner
said. âYou wonât mind the Keeley. It isnât
bad.â
âThe Keeley,â William Campbell said. âIt
isnât far from London.â He shut his eyes and
opened them, moving the eyelashes against the
sheet. âI just love sheets,â he said. He looked
at Mr. Turner.
âListen, you think Iâm drunk.â
âYou are drunk.â
âNo, Iâm not.â
âYouâre drunk and youâve had dtâs.â
âNo.â William Campbell held the sheet
around his head. âDear sheet,â he said. He
breathed against it gently. âPretty sheet. You
love me, donât you, sheet? Itâs all in the price
of the room. Just like in Japan. No,â he
said. âListen Billy, dear Sliding Billy, I have
a surprise for you. Iâm not drunk. Iâm hopped
to the eyes.â
âNo,â said Mr. Turner.
âTake a look.â William Campbell pulled
up the right sleeve of his pyjama jacket under
the sheet, then shoved the right forearm out.
âLook at that.â On the forearm, from just
above the wrist to the elbow, were small blue
circles around tiny dark blue punctures. The
circles almost touched one another. âThatâs
the new development,â William Campbell said.
âI drink a little now once in a while, just to
drive the wolf out of the room.â
âThey got a cure for that, âSliding Billyââ¯â
Turner said.
âNo,â William Campbell said. âThey
havenât got a cure for anything.â
âYou canât just quit like that, Billy,â Turner
said. He sat on the bed.
âBe careful of my sheet,â William Campbell
said.
âYou canât just quit at your age and take to
pumping yourself full of that stuff just because
you got in a jam.â
âThereâs a law against it. If thatâs what you
mean.â
âNo, I mean you got to fight it out.â
Billy Campbell caressed the sheet with his
lips and his tongue. âDear sheet,â he said. âI
can kiss this sheet and see right through it at the
same time.â
âCut it out about the sheet. You canât just
take to that stuff, Billy.â
William Campbell shut his eyes. He was
beginning to feel a slight nausea. He knew
that this nausea would increase steadily, without
there ever being the relief of sickness, until
something were done against it. It was at this
point that he suggested that Mr. Turner have
a drink. Mr. Turner declined. William Campbell
took a drink from the bottle. It was a temporary
measure. Mr. Turner watched him.
Mr. Turner had been in this room much longer
than he should have been, he had many things
to do; although living in daily association with
people who used drugs, he had a horror of
drugs, and he was very fond of William Campbell;
he did not wish to leave him. He was
very sorry for him and he felt a cure might
help. He knew there were good cures in Kansas
City. But he had to go. He stood up.
âListen, Billy,â William Campbell said, âI
want to tell you something. Youâre called âSliding
Billy.â Thatâs because you can slide. Iâm
called just Billy. Thatâs because I never could
slide at all. I canât slide, Billy. I canât slide.
It just catches. Every time I try it, it catches.â
He shut his eyes. âI canât slide, Billy. Itâs
awful when you canât slide.â
âYes,â said âSliding Billyâ Turner.
âYes, what?â William Campbell looked at
him.
âYou were saying.â
âNo,â said William Campbell. âI wasnât
saying. It must have been a mistake.â
âYou were saying about sliding.â
âNo. It couldnât have been about sliding.
But listen, Billy, and Iâll tell you a secret. Stick
to sheets, Billy. Keep away from women and
horses and, andââ he stopped ââeagles, Billy.
If you love horses youâll get horse-sâ, and if
you love eagles youâll get eagle-sâ.â He
stopped and put his head under the sheet.
âI got to go,â said âSliding Billyâ Turner.
âIf you love women youâll get a dose,â William
Campbell said. âIf you love horsesâââ
âYes, you said that.â
âSaid what?â
âAbout horses and eagles.â
âOh, yes. And if you love sheets.â He
breathed on the sheet and stroked his nose
against it. âI donât know about sheets,â he said.
âI just started to love this sheet.â
âI have to go,â Mr. Turner said. âI got
a lot to do.â
âThatâs all right,â William Campbell said.
âEverybodyâs got to go.â
âI better go.â
âAll right, you go.â
âAre you all right, Billy?â
âI was never so happy in my life.â
âAnd youâre all right?â
âIâm fine. You go along. Iâll just lie here
for a little while. Around noon Iâll get up.â
But when Mr. Turner came up to William
Campbellâs room at noon William Campbell
was sleeping and as Mr. Turner was a man who
knew what things in life were very valuable he
did not wake him.
